[[File:Thayer Public Library, Braintree MA.jpg|thumb|Current library, built 1999]]
â
'''Thayer Public Library''' is a public [[library]] located in the town of [[Braintree, Massachusetts]] with a collection of over 125,000 materials in many formats.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.thayerpubliclibrary.net/about.html Thayer Public Library, About the Library<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The library is a member of the [[Old Colony Library Network]].<ref>[http://www.ocln.org/wp-public/?page_id=24 Old Colony Library Network<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
+
The '''Thayer Public Library''' is a public [[library]] located in the town of [[Braintree, Massachusetts]] with 102,000 [[book]]s, 200 [[Magazine|periodical]] subscriptions, and 8,000 [[videotape|videos]], [[DVD]]s, music [[Compact Disk|CDs]], and [[audiobook]]s.<ref name=autogenerated1>[http://www.thayerpubliclibrary.net/about.html Thayer Public Library, About the Library<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> The library is a member of the [[Old Colony Library Network]].<ref>[http://www.ocln.org/wp-public/?page_id=24 Old Colony Library Network<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==About the library==
==About the library==
â
The library is named for [[Sylvanus Thayer|General Sylvanus Thayer]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> who helped found it through a $20,000 bequest in his will. The original building was dedicated June 4, 1874, and opened to the public in September of the same year. The building is listed on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places. <ref name=autogenerated1 /> It operated as a library until 1953, when it was replaced by a larger building across the street.<ref>[http://www.thayerpubliclibrary.net/about.html About]</ref> The 1874 building was occupied by the Braintree Water Department for many years, but is currently vacant. This building is included in the [[List of Registered Historic Places in Norfolk County, Massachusetts]].<ref>[http://www.nationalregisterofhistoricplaces.com/MA/Norfolk/state.html National Register of Historical Places - MASSACHUSETTS (MA), Norfolk County<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
+
The library is named for [[Sylvanus Thayer|General Sylvanus Thayer]],<ref name=autogenerated1 /> who helped found it through a $20,000 bequest in his will. The original building was dedicated June 4, 1874, and opened to the public in September of the same year.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> It operated as a library until 1953, when it was replaced by a larger building across the street.<ref>[http://www.thayerpubliclibrary.net/about.html About]</ref> The 1874 building was occupied by the Braintree Water Department for many years, but is currently vacant. This building is included in the [[List of Registered Historic Places in Norfolk County, Massachusetts]].<ref>[http://www.nationalregisterofhistoricplaces.com/MA/Norfolk/state.html National Register of Historical Places - MASSACHUSETTS (MA), Norfolk County<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In 1997 the 1953 library building was razed to and replaced by the current three-story brick [[Postmodern architecture|postmodern]] building that opened in 1999.
In 1997 the 1953 library building was razed to and replaced by the current three-story brick [[Postmodern architecture|postmodern]] building that opened in 1999.
  +
==Antitrust lawsuit participation==
  +
In March 2008, the Thayer Public Library was notified that it was among several libraries in [[Massachusetts]] that would share in the 2002 settlement of an [[antitrust]] case that was brought against [[Bertelsmann Music Group|BMG]], [[EMI Music]], [[Warner-Elektra-Atlantic|Warner Music Group]], and [[Sony Music Entertainment]]<ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/5226945/ Librarians: Free CDs too much of a good thing - U.S. news - MSNBC.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> by the [[antitrust]] division of [[Attorney General of Massachusetts|Massachusetts Attorney General]] [[Martha Coakley]]âs office, along with the Attorneys General of thirty-nine other states. The lawsuit was settled in 2002 for $144 million, and alleged that the music distribution companies illegally inflated the price of CDs by requiring retailers to sell them at or above a set level in order to qualify for substantial advertising funding.<ref>''[[The New York Times]]'', October 1, 2002</ref>
  +   +
The library is expected to receive a minimum of $300, which must be used exclusively for its music related programs or projects.<ref>''[[The Patriot Ledger]]'', March 8, 2008</ref>
  +   +
